section.title: Carbon
section.content: Carbon C 18.5% C Atomic Number = 6 Atomic Weight and Isotopes =12 is stable =13 is stable =14 is radioactive
section.related-content:
Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6. It is nonmetallic and tetra-valent—making four electrons available to form covalent chemical bonds. It belongs to group 4 of the periodic table. The isotopes of a chemical element have the same atomic number and nearly identical chemical behavior but with a different atomic mass. Three isotopes of carbon, occur naturally. Isotopes of carbon with atomic weight 12 and 13 are stable, while atomic weight 14 is a radionuclide, decaying with a half-life of about 5,730 years. Carbon is one of the few elements known since antiquity.
Carbon is the 15th most abundant element in the Earth's crust, and the fourth most abundant element in the universe by mass after hydrogen, helium, and oxygen. Carbon's abundance, its unique diversity of organic compounds, and its unusual ability to form polymers at the temperatures commonly encountered on Earth enables this element to serve as a common element of all known life. It is the second most abundant element in the human body by mass (about 18.5%) after oxygen.

section.title: Allotropes
section.content: Allotropes Eight allotropes of carbon: Lonsdaleite C60 (Buckminsterfullerene) C540 C70 Graphite Amorphous Carbon Diamond Carbon nanotubes
section.related-content: The atoms of carbon can bond together in different ways, termed allotropes of carbon. The best known are diamond,  amorphous carbon and graphite. The physical properties of carbon vary widely with the allotropic form. For example, graphite is opaque and black while diamond is highly transparent. Graphite is soft enough to form a streak on paper while diamond is the hardest naturally occurring material known. Graphite is a good electrical conductor while diamond has a low electrical conductivity. Under normal conditions, diamond, carbon nanotubes, and graphene have the highest thermal conductivities of all known materials. All carbon allotropes are solids under normal conditions, with graphite being the most thermodynamically stable form at standard temperature and pressure. They are chemically resistant and require high temperature to react even with oxygen.

section.title: What is Carbon Black
section.content: A paracrystalline carbon consisting of at least 95 % carbon by weight. Produce by partial combustion of hydrocarbon (natural gas, acetylene, coal tars, petroleum residual oils). Carbon black is not soot (soot is amorphous and is typically high in PAH content). Carbon black is produced under controlled conditions. Used in rubber, plastics, inks paints. Provides color and enhanced performance properties. Marketed as a granule and a powder. What is Carbon Black
section.related-content:
Carbon black is a form of paracrystalline carbon that has a high surface-area-to-volume ratio, albeit lower than that of activated carbon. Today it is an industrial material produced mainly by the incomplete combustion of heavy hydrocarbon liquids such as F-C-C tar, coal tar, or ethylene cracker tar and hydrocarbon gases such as natural gas and acetylene. It is dissimilar to soot in its much higher surface-area-to-volume ratio and significantly lower polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon content. Unlike soot, in today’s modern factories carbon black is produced under precisely controlled conditions.
Carbon black is mainly used as a reinforcing filler in tires and other rubber products. In plastics, paints, and inks, carbon black is used as a color pigment and has properties that can inhibit deterioration of polymers from ultraviolet light and provide conductivity. Generally, carbon black is marketed in granular form with “pellets” that are a few millimeters in diameter or in an agglomerated powder form. The granular form is usually preferred by customers since it transports easier and causes less environmental issues.

section.title: What is Carbon Black
section.content: Elemental analysis of Carbon Black What is Carbon Black Elemental analysis of Carbon Black Carbon (C) 95.0 – 99.5% Hydrogen (H) 0.2 – 1.3% Oxygen (O) 0.2 - 0.5% Nitrogen (N) 0.0 - 1.0% Sulphur (S) 0.1 - 3.0% Other impurities ppm Metal, Refractory and Salt Depends on S in raw material
section.related-content: Carbon black purity is reflected in the quality of the raw materials used in production and contaminates that are caused by contact with gases and surfaces in the carbon black process. In general, carbon black is over 95% pure carbon. Sulfur in the carbon black generally comes the feedstock and is a residual in the carbon black as well as a component in the gases exhausted from the process. Fractions of metal, refractory and salts result in impurities in the carbon black that could be detrimental to sensitive applications. Many carbon black processes have special non-corrosive metals and use high purity water and other ingredients in the recipe to create a very pure product for special applications. Since carbon black is adsorptive in nature the surface chemistry can be very complex as a result of the contact the carbon black has in the process. Sometimes special additives are used to give special properties to the carbon black.

section.title: What is Carbon Black
section.content: Some general characteristics of Carbon Black: What is Carbon Black Particle aggregates Black pigment Highly adsorptive Morphologically paracrystalline carbon Very small particle size (10-500 nm) High surface area (6 – 1200 m2/g) Chemically almost pure carbon Nanoparticle
section.related-content: In applications, carbon black is generally used as a black pigmenting agent. It is highly adsorptive and hygroscopic so it must be stored in dry conditions to avoid water being adsorbed into the aggregate. The shape of a carbon black aggregate is shown in the electron micrograph above. The particles are the round nodules within the aggregate. So when measuring particle size we are measuring the “average” diameter of the nodules shown by the distance between the blue arrows in the photograph. The distance between the red arrows is an approximation of the aggregate size which is an aggregate of many particles or nodules. The particle size may be measured in nanometers so carbon black can be considered as on of the first nanoparticles investigated in the scientific world.

section.title: Manufacturing of Carbon Black
section.content: 30,000 BCA – Rudimentary form in cave dwellings. Manufacturing of Carbon Black 1200 BCA – Manufactured by Chinese and Egyptians. 15th Century – Movable type for printing. 1900 – Reinforcement of rubber for auto industry. 1941 – Oil furnace black patented by Phillips Petroleum Corporation Limited. Today – New generation oil furnace Black reactor.
section.related-content:
Carbon black was used in a rudimentary form in cave dwellings over 30 thousand years ago.
About 3 thousand years ago, a primitive form of manufacturing carbon black was shown in Egyptian heiroglypics and about the same time Chinese documents show writings using inks made with carbon blacks.
Once printing became common in the 15th century production of carbon black for printing inks increase and with the advent of automobiles using rubber tires became a major mode of transportation, carbon black for reinforcing rubber brought about further growth of the industry. In the early 20th century most of the carbon black was manufactured by natural gas. A new method was developed prior to World War II, the oil furnace process, that led the industry to produce products using liquid hydrocarbons such as petroleum tars and coal tars. The oil furnace process has continued to be refined and improved until today, the industry is highly efficient with many high quality and unique products.

section.title: Carbon Black Process Model of 21st Century
section.content: Carbon Black Process Model of 21st Century Reactor Heat Recovery Beading Waste Gases
section.related-content: In the oil furnace carbon black process, the reactor is the core of the operation that forms the carbon black particle. This reactor is precisely controlled so the carbon black is uniform and high quality. It leaves the reactor in powder form and is pelletized to granules in a pelletizer or beader. The process of making carbon black is high in energy consumption. Therefore, heat generated in the process is captured and used to heat raw materials to make the energy consumption of the reactor more efficient. Also, the by-product gases formed during the carbon black production are used to heat water and make steam and also to dry the wet beaded carbon blacks. The schematic above depicts an efficient modern day carbon black process that generates electrical power and provides heating for community use.

section.title: Carbon Black at Himadri in Everyday life
section.content: Carbon Black at Himadri in Everyday life
section.related-content: Carbon black produced at Himadri is found in all types of products that you see in everyday life. Almost everything around you that is black contains carbon black, from the tires on your automobile, the ink on your newspaper, garbage bags, to plastics found in wires and cables. Even the fabrics in black clothing that are made of polymers have carbon black.

section.related-content:
As you can see from this table, most of the carbon black in the world is used in the components of rubber tires. A tire may have many types of carbon black in it depending on the service required; for instance, life of the tire tread or reduced heat build-up in the sidewalls.
The second most carbon black consumption is in non-tire rubber. Many rubber products on an automobile including the weather stripping around windows, belts, hoses and even mounts for cushioning vibration have carbon black in them.
This shows that 90% of the applications for carbon blacks are in rubber products.
The non-rubber applications include pigmenting plastics, inks and paints. Also, in this segment are many specialty applications that provide ultraviolet light protection in products such as plastic pipes and electrical conductivity in products such as power cables.

section.title: Global Production Capacity of Carbon Black
section.content: Global Production Capacity of Carbon Black 17 Billion 7 Billion
section.related-content: In 2018, global capacity of carbon black reached approximately 17 billion metric tons. In the late 20th century, the North American and European economic regions were producing a very large share of the carbon black in the world. However, capacity did not grow in these areas due to a variety of factors including raw material costs and environmental pressures. By 2018, as seen in this table, Chinese carbon black production capacity at approximately 7.0 billion tons annually was the largest in the world and represented about 40% of the global capacity. In the 20th century, Chinese carbon black was, in general, a low quality commodity product but with the influx of modern global manufacturing technology into the Chinese industry, currently many Chinese products can now compete in the international market on both a cost and quality basis.
